title: Installation
text:
Installation
To work with the realestateCH package, first clone the repository:
git clone https://github.com/adeponti/FinalProject.git
cd FinalProject
Install the package in editable mode:
pip install -e .
Run the test suite to confirm everything works:
pytest
You now have access to all functions for loading, cleaning, analyzing and visualizing Swiss real estate data.

title: Overview
text:
realestateCH: Swiss Real Estate Analytics
This package provides tools for loading, cleaning, analyzing, and visualizing Swiss real estate data (rent & buy markets).
You can use it to:

Load raw datasets

Clean inconsistent or missing values

Compute rent and buy metrics

Produce visualizations

Integrate into dashboards (Role 3)

title: Examples
text:
Here are a few practical examples showing how to use the functions included in the realestateCH Python package.
These examples can be adapted directly in Jupyter notebooks, Python scripts, or in the dashboard built in Role 3.



from realestateCH.load import load_data
from realestateCH.clean import clean_data

rent = load_data("data_raw/Total-Rent.csv")
buy = load_data("data_raw/Total-Buy.csv")

rent = clean_data(rent)
buy = clean_data(buy)




from realestateCH.metrics import (
    compute_rent_per_m2,
    compute_buy_price_per_m2
)

rent["rent_per_m2"] = compute_rent_per_m2(rent)
buy["price_per_m2"] = compute_buy_price_per_m2(buy)




merged = rent.merge(
    buy,
    on="zip_code",
    how="inner",
    suffixes=("_rent", "_buy")
)




from realestateCH.metrics import price_to_rent_ratio

ratio_df = price_to_rent_ratio(buy, rent)
ratio_df.head()




from realestateCH.plots import plot_rent_distribution

plot_rent_distribution(rent)




from realestateCH.plots import (
    plot_average_rent_per_canton,
    plot_average_buy_price_per_canton
)

plot_average_rent_per_canton(rent)
plot_average_buy_price_per_canton(buy)

These examples illustrate the core operations supported by the package: loading, cleaning, merging, computing metrics, and visualizing real estate data.

title: API Reference
text:
API Reference
This page lists all the main public functions provided by the
realestateCH Python package.
They are grouped into four categories: - Loading - Cleaning - Metrics - Plots



Loading

load_data(path)
Load a CSV file from disk into a pandas DataFrame.


load_rent_data()
Load and automatically clean the Total-Rent dataset.


load_buy_data()
Load and automatically clean the Total-Buy dataset.




Cleaning

clean_data(df)
Clean the dataset by: - converting numeric columns
- removing invalid or missing entries
- dropping duplicates
- standardizing canton names




Metrics

compute_rent_per_m2(df)
Compute rent price per square meter.


compute_buy_price_per_m2(df)
Compute buy price per square meter.


price_to_rent_ratio(buy_df, rent_df)
Merge rent+buy datasets on ZIP code and compute the price-to-rent ratio.


average_rent_per_m2_by_canton(df)
Compute average rent per m² for each canton.


rank_cantons_by_rent(df)
Rank cantons by average rent per m².




Plots

plot_average_rent_per_canton(df)
Create a bar plot showing average rent per canton.


plot_price_to_rent_ratio_hist(df)
Plot a histogram of the price-to-rent ratio values.

This API reference summarizes all core functionalities available in the package.

title: Get started
text:
This page shows a minimal end-to-end example of how to use the realestateCH package with the project data.
We will:

Load the raw rent dataset

Clean the data

Compute rent price per square meter

Create a simple plot by canton




from realestateCH.load import load_data
from realestateCH.clean import clean_data
from realestateCH.metrics import compute_rent_per_m2
from realestateCH.plots import plot_average_rent_per_canton




Here we use the file data_raw/Total-Rent.csv that was collected in Role 1.
rent_df = load_data("data_raw/Total-Rent.csv")




We apply the cleaning logic defined in the package: numeric conversion, removal of invalid rows, duplicates, etc.
clean_rent_df = clean_data(rent_df)




clean_rent_df["rent_per_m2"] = compute_rent_per_m2(clean_rent_df)




Finally, we create a simple bar plot that shows the average rent price per m² for each canton.
plot_average_rent_per_canton(clean_rent_df)
This basic workflow is the starting point for more advanced analysis and for the interactive dashboard developed in Role 3.
